data.title: Fannye Rose Shore (1916-1994)

Biography

Dinah Shore is Notable.

Family

Dinah, aka Fanny (Fannye) or Frances, Rose Shore was born on February 29, 1916, in Winchester, Tennessee. Her parents were Solomon Aron Shore and Ann Stein.[1]Her father ran a department store and her mother was an opera singer.[2]Fanny, as she was called as a child, had an older sister named Bessie. Bessie was about eight years older than Fanny.

Dinah's parents were immigrants from Russia. Their native tongue is listed as Hebrew.

Dinah had polio when she was just a child at 18 months old. Like so many others, Dinah walked with a slight limp after her recovery.[3]

When Dinah was sixteen, her mother died of a heart attack.[4]

Dinah earned a degree in Sociology from Vanderbilt university.[5]

Marriages

Dinah married George Montgomery in 1943. They had a daughter Melissa Ann "Missy" Montgomery, in January 1948. Later the couple adopted a son, named John. George and Dinah were divorced in 1963. [6]

Dinah married Maurice Fabian Smith in 1963 and divorced him the following year in 1964.[7]

U.S. Census

1920 - Fanny Rose age three; Winchester, Franklin, Tennessee 1930 -

Career

Awards

Television

Eddie Cantor Show "Time To Smile" 1940[8]

Music

Dinah's first recording was with Xavier Cugat in1939 under the RCA Victor label. In 1940 she was the soloist for Xavier Cugat's The Breeze and I.

The Breeeze and I

Her first hit was Yes, My Darling Daughter (Ukranian Folk Song) with lyrics by Jack Lawrence.[9]

My Darling Daughter by Dinah Shore - 1941

Buttons and Bows; music by Jay Livingston with lyrics by Ray Evans. Recorded by several artists including The Dinning Sisters, Betty Rhodes, Evelyn Knight an Betty Garrett. Gene Autry also had a recording of this popular song of 1948. However, Dinah's was the most popular version.[10]

Buttons and Bows

Buttons and Bows Lyrics

East is east and west is west

And the wrong one I have chose

Let's go where they keep on wearin'

Those frills and flowers and buttons and bows

Rings and things and buttons and bows.

Don't bury me in this prairie

Take me where the cement grows

Let's move down to some big town

Where they love a gal by the cut o' her clothes

And you'll stand out, in buttons and bows.

I'll love you in buckskin

Or skirts that you've homespun

But I'll love ya' longer, stronger

Where yer friends don't tote a gun

My bones denounce the buckboard bounce

And the cactus hurts my toes

Let's vamoose where gals keep a-usin'

Those silks and satins and linen that shows

And I'm all yours in buttons and bows.

Gimme eastern trimmin' where women are women

In high silk hose and peek-a-boo clothes

And French perfume that rocks the room

And I'm all yours in buttons and bows.

Buttons and bows, buttons and bows

Source: LyricFind

Songwriters: Jay Livingston / Ray Evans

Buttons and Bows lyrics © Sony/ATV Music Publishing LLC, Kobalt Music :::Publishing Ltd.

Death and Burial

Dinah Shore died on 24 Feb 1994, in Cathedral City, Riverside County, California.[11]
